body:
I tested, seems to fix the issue. Normally, if one install the NBM with the fix, then one needs another round of update to get the updated nb-javac. But we could manually put the nb-javac modules on the distro AUC.

One thing that is missing is an update to the spec version of the updatecenters module, but we can do that on the cherry pick, master has updated spec version anyway.

FYI, cherry-pick:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1659

Original PR:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1604
I'll go with the smaller batik library subset approach then.
Force-pushing made some earlier reviews unavailable, but the requested changes have been taken into account, so marking these reviews as "dismissed" now.
There seems to be some transient Travis failures... I had it all green yesterday. Will wait until I can make it pass again before merging.

Two subsequent Travis builds, on the same unchanged codebase, yielded one transient test failure each, but in different test jobs.

https://travis-ci.org/apache/netbeans/builds/616390107
https://travis-ci.org/apache/netbeans/builds/616369975

So I take this to mean that all tests have passed... (since each of the failed jobs, "Test ide modules" and "Test platform modules, Batch 1", passed once in the other Travis run)

Be aware that version 7.0.5 has some incompatibilities/problems that still have to be addressed:

https://github.com/javacc/javacc/pull/73

Hi Tobias,

Thanks for pointing this out, I will review it.

El dom., 24 nov. 2019 a las 17:35, Tobias (<notifications@github.com>)
escribió:

> still has to be adressed:
>
> javacc/javacc#73 <https://github.com/javacc/javacc/pull/73>

Let's the play begin.

Nice work!

Error when building with cmd

ant -DthreadCount=16 -quiet -silent -nice 10 -Dcluster.config=full -Ddo.build.windows.launchers=true build build-nbms generate-uc-catalog build-source-zips -Dpermit.jdk9.builds=true -Djavac.compilerargs=-nowarn -Dbuild.compiler.deprecation=false;


/root/NetBeansProjects/netbeans-src/nbbuild/build.xml:660: Target "all-o.n.swing.laf.dark" does not exist in the project "main". It is used from target "nbmerge-build-one-cluster".

Spurious Travis failures are somewhat par for the course - you can retrigger them from the Travis UI assuming your accounts are connected?  Speaking of which, why do the commits show as ultorg rather than you personally?  Author email should ideally be your Apache one.

Thanks @jlahoda Will merge and test with build with aim for vote and push to users this week.

So, just to double check, we need to ship the following 3 NBMs?

- org-netbeans-modules-updatecenters.nbm
- org-netbeans-libs-javacapi.nbm
- org-netbeans-libs-javacimpl.nbm

Thanks @matthiasblaesing Will merge and test with view to vote and pushing update this week.

To double check, looking at just shipping org-netbeans-modules-html-lexer.nbm ?

It's my real name and email in the git logs, but it didn't match the email that was associated with this github account. Now fixed to avoid confusion. (I prefer to use a real email address over the Apache one, to avoid a proliferation of email addresses that I have to check or maintain...)

> you can retrigger them from the Travis UI assuming your accounts are connected
That's easier, will try that next time...
o.n.swing.laf.dark is another PR for Dark Nimbus and Dark Metal

BUILD FAILED
/home/travis/build/apache/netbeans/nbbuild/build.xml:1614: Failed VerifyLibsAndLicenses test(s):
Some license files have incorrect headers
ide/db.sql.visualeditor/external/javacc-7.0.5-license.txt refers to nonexistent nbbuild/licenses/BSD-javacc-7.0.5
java/performance/external/javacc-7.0.5-license.txt refers to nonexistent nbbuild/licenses/BSD-javacc-7.0.5

It wouldn't surprise me if the continuous build fails - this patch changes the workflow of first-start of the IDE, and for running tests without popping up the UI, it would need to alter the netbeans.conf file or similar to cause the launch script to skip that step and launch the IDE.
@jlahoda : Just another reminder.
Yes shipping `org-netbeans-modules-html-lexer.nbm` will be enough. The changes in `php.smarty` are the unittests, that Junichi provided and are not needed at runtime.

The name shown on github is mostly useless, as github tries to be clever. If you need the real information, only `git log` (or its companions) show the truth. That said, in these cases, where the github data is not useable, "Squash and Merge" must not be used from the github GUI, as it destroys the valid author information (git rebase does this much better).
Looks good. Thank you.

Unit tests in css.lib module are failing as I'd missed that the Zoom CSS property is only currently defined in the webkit.properties file (as `<match-anything>`).

Could somebody with the appropriate permissions please label this PR as Work In Progress, whilst I think/work on a good solution for dealing with browser specific properties where we don't have a regular CSS property to proxy to?
Will test it until the weekend, I know it is work in progress, just testing and will tell you what I think :)

@geertjanw yes, seems to apply OK locally, but a bit concerned about the structure of this one compared to other updates.  Still, if it does cause any issues in updating we can always revert the update catalog reference for that one NBM.
Hey @jlahoda is the option hidden atm? I pulled your PR, built it, but I can't see your options.
OK, tests passed so merging.

Tested git master (commit aec421c854cfa5199ac4a3e901387071503a6ece). On Windows 10, ant 1.9.14, Adopt OpenJDK 8u232
```
ant build-source-config
```
runs cleanly.
@nigjo are you still interested in this? I checked the changes and they look sane (I did a double rebase and then I get a single minimal diff)
@lkishalmi is this still relevant? it seems to be stale, if so it would be good to remove.
@sarveshkesharwani is this still relevant?
Not relevant any more. Only test, so it is closed.
Merged via https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/e1ef6a5692716db1efda223cec99d8c6981cf131. Thank you.

Got a mail from Rolf Dockter:
Hi Lazlo,

sorry for the delay (see your email below) and thanks for bringing this to my attention. 

We're in the process of revising the licensing info.

Therefore I inform you in this way that we give permission to use the logo under the following condition:

For Our Customers and the General Public

Gradle embraces “fair use” of its trademarks.  As such, you may use the foregoing trademarks to identify Gradle and its family of products, for example, in your website, blog, news article, or product review, without our written consent, as long as you use them without modification or deceptive intent and do not cause a likelihood of confusion between yourself and Gradle’s brands.
If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask.

Best,
Rolf
Well I guess now we have to turn to Apache Legal for consultancy, how to handle this.

I did a manual squash, saw no failing Travis tests, and merged. I also tested a private build of the platform with my NetBeans Platform app, which makes extensive use of SVG icon loading.

Added the following issues for the future:
* [NETBEANS-3469 Cache PNG versions of loaded SVG icons](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-3469)
* [NETBEANS-3468 Make HiDPI (Retina) icons work in MacOS menu bar](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-3468)

Note NetBeans does not bundle the connector due to licensing reasons. So, incrementing that version seems like a good idea, but it's only used for one test...

If you are working in this area, take a look at MySQLProcedure.java and `.createValue` which mentions http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=41269 which has been closed for a decade.
Bit tied up with other things to review properly, but +1 to the principle - great idea!

I don't now if I already said it, but I would just use this:

https://github.com/simple-icons/simple-icons/blob/develop/icons/gradle.svg
https://github.com/simple-icons/simple-icons/blob/develop/icons/groovy.svg

The license is sane (CC-0):

https://github.com/simple-icons/simple-icons/blob/develop/LICENSE.md

and we are already using the npm icon from the same source. See here:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1034
Details:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1034#issuecomment-453753472

Well I'd rather not go that route. That is probably the same svg Gradle had created, and we sue that for light LaF-s we use another one for dark. Though the fair trade terms are pretty open, I'd not go through a third party license.
Let's just wait what Apache Legal team say to this. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LEGAL-495

I'm not a lawyer, BUT the basic rule I learned: If there is not license, you may not use it. I.e. you can use my code because I gave it away under the ALv2 or other licenses. For the record: You claim, that the source I cited is violating copyright law (just saying).
Looks sane - thank you.

> You claim, that the source I cited is violating copyright law (just saying).
I think, most likely unintentionally, but they do that.

Ok - I'll look forward to the solution - I don't see a license presented by gradle (just some vague text). The claim, that the referenced logo is a copy is unproven. I'll sunsubscribe from this PR then.
Looks sane.
Merged via https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/37ef73e45cc5d6ff438b4dbb543ca4863a14d719.
Looks sane.

@matthiasblaesing please remain on this PR. Your second pair of eyes are really useful here. The vague text from Gradle side makes it harder than it should be. It would be hard for simple icons as well, I just think they care less of such things.
There must be a project opened (so that ergonomics enable the editor). Then I see Tools/Options/Editor/Language Servers.
Thx, will check it. Didn't check the code deep yet, just saw, that you have an option created :)
I whould like to see this in master. We are using this change in our RCP for a while now without any issues. (other than we can now use ant extension points)

@ebarboni Hi, excuse me, do you have an editable version of the software agreement you need? (https://www.apache.org/licenses/software-grant-template.pdf). Our (JetBrains) legal department are now processing it, and they need to change something.

Comment from legal department: It (software agreement) is very basic and missing some key provisions, such as governing law etc.

Please don't use a RAT exclude. IMHO this must be part of license. It must hit everybody looking at the LICENSE file, that the gradle icons are _not_ freesoftware and that they must follow the same restrictions as we have to do.
I suggest to create a "gradle-icon-license" file (I won't bikeshed on this) in the licenses folder, quote the email from grade in their, add a reference to the apache legal issue (I assume someone there said "yeah, its ok") in there, reference that file from license and you should be done.
That way everybody is aware of the potentially critical license terms that gradle provided and can't say he/she was not warned.
@nigjo ok, changeset was rebased and squashed and is now applied to master: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/f22b10b0b640033d9ba5e54180cb276d91f447cb . Thank you for your contribution.

Merging this as it makes the new LaF-s available in platform also fixing the the dark LaF is accidentally ended up in the extra cluster.
Travis is only failing the missing hibernate.
As always, thank you @matthiasblaesing for your wisdom! I think that's the best option anyone suggested so far.
@matthiasblaesing Travis is green save some unrelated failure of htmlui tests. So if you approve I'd merge this and let's be over it for once. Thank you for your support in this!

@MeroRai Maybe, should submit an issue to the JIRA if possible before you create a PR: https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/NETBEANS/issues

Then, please also see this: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NETBEANS/Submitting+Pull+Request+on+Apache+NetBeans

About failing Travis: https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/dd164f1972f688db48cdb8c5fdc969f35bbd539e80d0497c1931298c@%3Cdev.netbeans.apache.org%3E

Thank you for your contribution :)
Wow, brilliant.

Huh.
Thank you and welcome here!
It seems Flatlaf is pretty swift on releases. I'm also tinkering on a gruvbox theme based on Flatlaf.
So I've thought it would be better to move the actual flatlaf jar into a separate library embedder module.
I'm just finished PR, and it also contains the 0.20 upgrade.
I hope you don't mind if I'd close this PR in favor of that one.
Agreed.

> It seems Flatlaf is pretty swift on releases.

Yes, currently pushing FlatLaf forward to reach 1.0 in the next months...

> I hope you don't mind if I'd close this PR in favor of that one.

No problem 👍 

BTW many thanks for adding FlatLaf to NetBeans. This is amazing.
Started the FlatLaf project only 3 months ago and now it is in NetBeans...

Well, Thanks for Flatlaf as well I think NetBeans badly needs a good flexible HiDPI aware LaF.
Closed in favor of #1699

Well, I think our utilities module would welcome a such a JDK version parsing class.
Please consider implementing the Comparable interface. The IDE_JDK_VERSION shall be final or private (as you have an access method for it).
I also had a look at this and with increased verbosity of the TestNG tests, I saw timeouts in the test preparation methods. Maybe we should just bump the timeouts from 9s to 30s?
It can be a good fix, but can we remove the timeouts directly instead change these?
Valid question - I admit, that I'm neither to deep in TestNG nor in the htmlui. But considering that stable unittest should not run into timeouts, that would also be a valid approach (IMHO).
I'm going to edit this pull request to remove timeouts and test if tests are stable before merge.

Thinking about this issue a little more, the whole point of the EventBroadcaster is to translate tree events into table events.  

If we allow any tree modification during tree events, then the EventBroadcaster should always be the last listener to run for all tree events (not the just the one raised in this issue).

The fix above which inserts new listeners at the start of the list works, but it isn't obvious why this needs to be done.  It might be better to refactor the code so that the EventBroadcaster is explicitly the last listener to run - so it has a special status, and isn't part of the main list of other registered listeners.

I think this would make the intention of the code clearer.
@matthiasblaesing  I removed all timeouts and travis passes the build.

As the author of that code, sounds good to me.  Listener ordering bugs are
painful to debug (I once spent a couple of days chasing down a bug that
only occurred when the look and feel had been changed without a restart,
because UI delegate listeners wind up called before instead of after
application listeners), so avoiding them is a fine thing.

-Tim

http://timboudreau.com
@timboudreau Thank you for your review!

Thanks for looking at this, but I'm -1 to it as is.  The reason I was going to port the PraxisLIVE hack that is also used with Darcula as an _interim_ solution is that the proliferation of UI specific code across modules like this is a problem.  This will not help the other dark LaFs either.  We should move to removing hard-coded colours throughout and use colours from the UI properties.  And ideally would remove all LaF-specific code.

Using colors from UI defaults would be of course the much better solution.
I just made the minimum changes to avoid any impact on other LaFs.
Is this still relevant?

Surely the way to do that is to replace the `isMetal` flag with a `useUIDefaultsColors` flag equivalent to 

```java
private final boolean useUIDefaultsColors = !UIManager.getLookAndFeel().isNativeLookAndFeel();
```
?
I also have a feeling those fields should not be `static`.

I've modified the PR, reverting the original fix (to not fire an event if there are no children).

TreePathSupport now explicitly fires EventBroadcaster as the last "listener", not making it part of the list of any other registered listeners.

This ensures that tree events are fully processed, including any tree modifications which occur in them, before they are translated into table events by the EventBroadcaster.

The OutlineSortTest unit test fails on current master (as expected), and passes with these changes.

The fields shall be not static as eventually we might support on the fly LaF changes.
isNativeLookAndFeel() is a kind of problematic it only returns true for Windows and probably Mac. On Linux the GtkLookAndFeel is based on Synth, so it is a kind of non-native native LaF.

I agree with Neil that there shall be no LaF specific hack in the code, especially no had coded colors. Though I would not vote against this change as this is the least intrusive to support Flatlaf based Look and Feels. On the other hand I'd create a JIRA issue to mark it to be sort out later.
We have several places where we patch the LaF all around the code base we shall mark them, and probably came up with a plan/guideline how to fix them. But that's another story.
Have changed the fields and related methods to non-static.

I tried to reproduce this, but somewhere between Chromium, the chrome connector missing from the apache netbeans build and some strange chromium behavior I got lost. Can you give steps how to reproduce the problem?
Thx for creating flatlat @DevCharly :)

@mklaehn it is not my change, I'm just the committer (not the author). And no the change is not the problem, the problem is either the travis infrastructure or the htmlui unittests. Given that this is a heisenbug, it is difficult to diagnose.

@mklaehn @matthiasblaesing I created this pull request to revert the changes in api.htmlui tests: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1710
Seems that the problem are with api.htmlui tests that fails randomly.

> @mklaehn it is not my change, I'm just the committer (not the author). And no the change is not the problem, the problem is either the travis infrastructure or the htmlui unittests. Given that this is a heisenbug, it is difficult to diagnose.

I saw your name at the top of the page wnd without reading further I made a bad assumption. Sorry for that.
Seems trivial. Let's move it to the master.
Seems trivial. Let's move it to the master.
Well as this is an solo occurrence, it would be probably better to write the thing with lambda instead.
Consider using lambda instead.
I've tried to keep the change small but using a lambda works for me too.
Done
For me this looks sane. Any reason not to merge it?

OK, retriggered the failing test, and withdrawing my -1, assuming we don't forget to look at a better fix later! :smile:

I still think longer term we should move to special-casing the LaFs that *shouldn't* use values from the UIDefaults (here and elsewhere).  Which as far as I can tell is usually the native ones - and to be a pedant - https://github.com/AdoptOpenJDK/openjdk-jdk8u/blob/master/jdk/src/share/classes/com/sun/java/swing/plaf/gtk/GTKLookAndFeel.java#L1559
Ok, closing this PR and will create another one with Split Maven modules.
Hi @graben, thanks for your great work, have you provided an Apache iCLA for your contributions or would you have an issue if you were to be asked to provide one?
Hi @geertjanw, I have not provided an iCLA, yet. Not needed one in the past. :-) If you liked me to provide one, no problem.
